title: Nonlinear sigma models solvable by the Aratyn-Ferreira-Zimerman ansatz

title_detail.value: Nonlinear sigma models solvable by the Aratyn-Ferreira-Zimerman ansatz

summary:
Nonlinear sigma models compatible with the aratyn-Ferreira-Zimerman ansatz
are discussed, the latter ansatz automatically leading to configurations with
definite values of the Hopf index. These models are allowed to involve a weight
factor which is a function of one of the toroidal coordinates. Depending on the
choice of the weight factor, the field equation takes various forms. In one
model with a special weight factor, the field equation turns out to be the
fifth Painleve equation. This model suggests the existence of a knot soliton
strictly confined in a finite spatial volume. Some other interesting cases are
also discussed.

summary_detail.value:
Nonlinear sigma models compatible with the aratyn-Ferreira-Zimerman ansatz
are discussed, the latter ansatz automatically leading to configurations with
definite values of the Hopf index. These models are allowed to involve a weight
factor which is a function of one of the toroidal coordinates. Depending on the
choice of the weight factor, the field equation takes various forms. In one
model with a special weight factor, the field equation turns out to be the
fifth Painleve equation. This model suggests the existence of a knot soliton
strictly confined in a finite spatial volume. Some other interesting cases are
also discussed.

author: Chang-Guang Shi
arxiv_comment: 19 pages. Two column style is changed to preprint style
fulltext:
Non-linear σ models solvable by the Aratyn-Ferreira-Zimerman
Ansatz
Minoru Hirayama and Chang-Guang Shi
Department of Physics, Toyama University, Toyama 930-8555,Japan

arXiv:hep-th/0109060v3 15 Feb 2002

Abstract
Nonlinear σ models compatible with the aratyn-Ferreira-Zimerman ansatz are discussed, the
latter ansatz automatically leading to configurations with definite values of the Hopf index. These
models are allowed to involve a weight factor which is a function of one of the toroidal coordinates.
Depending on the choice of the weight factor, the field equation takes various forms. In one model
with a special weight factor, the field equation turns out to be the fifth Painlevé equation. This
model suggests the existence of a knot soliton strictly confined in a finite spatial volume. Some
other interesting cases are also discussed.
PACS numbers: 11.10.Lm,02.30.Ik,03.50.-z

1

 I.

INTRODUCTION

In some recent papers, it was suggested that a class of relativistic field theories might
possess soliton solutions of knot type. Among them, the Faddeev-Skyrme O(3) nonlinear
σ model has been investigated most intensively[1, 2, 3, 4, 5]. This model concerns the real
scalar fields
n(x) = (n1 (x), n2 (x), n3 (x))

(1.1)

satisfying
n2 (x) = n(x) * n(x) =

3
X

na (x)na (x) = 1.

(1.2)

a=1

The Lagrangian density of this model is given by
LF (x) = c2 l2 (x) + c4 l4 (x),

(1.3)

l2 (x) = ∂μ n(x) * ∂ μ n(x),

(1.4)

l4 (x) = −Hμν (x)H μν (x),

(1.5)

Hμν (x) = n(x) * [∂μ n(x) × ∂ν n(x)]
= ǫabc na (x)∂μ nb (x)∂ν nc (x),

(1.6)

where c2 and c4 are constants. The static energy functional EF [n] associated with LF (x) is
given by
EF [n] =
ǫ2 (x) =

x = (x1 , x2 , x3 ),

with (x1 , x2 , x3 ) = (x, y, z) being Cartesian coordinates. If we assume that n(x) satisfy the
boundary condition
n(x) = (0, 0, 1) at |x| = ∞
2

(1.11)

 and that n(x) are regular for |x| < ∞, we can regard n as a mapping from S 3 to S 2 . It is
known that such mappings are classified by the topological number QH [n] called the Hopf
index, which is also a functional of n. Vakulenko and Kapitanskii and Kundu and Rybakov
found an inequality of the following type [6, 7, 8]:

3/4


[n]

(1.12)

where K is equal to 29/2 33/8 π 2 . Then a configuration of n(x) with QH [n] 6= 0 would be
stable against collapsing into a trivial configuration. Through a numerical analysis aided by
a parallel supercomputer, it was revealed that there indeed exist many interesting solitonic
configurations of n(x). For example, the configuration with QH [n] = 7 exhibits the topology
of a trefoil knot [5]. As for the model defined by LF (x), Faddeev and Niemi discussed that
it is intimately related to the low energy dynamics of the SU(2) non-Abelian gauge field [9].
The generalization to the case of the SU(N) gauge group was also given by them [10].
On the other hand, Aratyn, Ferreira, and Zimerman(AFZ) [11] considered the model
defined by
LAF Z (x) = [l4 (x)]3/4 .

(1.13)

The static energy functional EAFZ [n] deduced from LAFZ (x) is invariant under spatial scale
transformations, suggesting the possibility of stable solitonic solutions. With the aid of an
ansatz for n(x), which we call the AFZ ansatz and explain in the next section, they reduced
the static field equation for n(x) to an ordinary differential equation for a single function
and succeeded in solving it. In this way, they obtained an infinite number of solutions
with general values of the Hopf index. To state their ansatz, they made use of the toroidal
coordinates (η, ξ, φ) related to the Cartesian coordinates (x, y, z) by
a
sinh η cosφ,
q

y = sinh η sinφ,
q
a
z = sinξ,
q

x =

(1.14)

where a is a scale parameter of the dimension of length and q is defined by
q = coshη − cosξ.
3

(1.15)

 In this paper, we consider nonlinear σ models defined by the following L2 (x), L4 (x), and
L2+4 (x):
q
μ(η) l2 (x),
a
a
L4 (x) = ν(η) l4 (x),
q
L2+4 (x) = g2 L2 (x) + g4 L4 (x),
L2 (x) =

(1.16)
(1.17)
(1.18)

where μ(η) and ν(η) are real functions of η and g2 and g4 are constants. In contrast to
LAF Z (x), the time derivatives of fields appear only quadratically in L2 (x), L4 (x), and
L2+4 (x). Just like EAFZ [n], the static energy functionals associated with these models are
invariant under spatial scale transformations. It turns out that the AFZ ansatz is also applicable to these models. In the case of L4 (x), the field equation is solvable for general
ν(η). Thus we also obtain an infinite number of solitonic solutions with general values of
the Hopf index. As for the case of L2 (x) with general μ(η), we are led to a field equation
that somewhat resembles the fifth Painlevé equation [12, 13]. For a special choice of μ(η),
we indeed obtain the fifth Painlevé equation. Since the solutions of Painlevé equations have
movable poles, we are led to the interesting possibility of knot solitons strictly confined in
finite spatial volumes. For another choice of μ(η), the field equation is solvable in terms of
the Jacobi elliptic function. Even the complicated case L2+4 (x) can be discussed through
the AFZ ansatz. Although the Faddeev-Skyrme model is not easy to investigate analytically,
the analysis of the models defined by Eqs. (1.16)-(1.18) seems much easier. Although they
are not Lorentz invariant, we investigate them with the hope that they might reveal some
unexpected features of knot solitons.
This paper is organized as follows. In Sec. II, we review the AFZ ansatz and the Hopf
index briefly. In Sec. III, we discuss the reason why the forms of L2 (x) and L4 (x) are
selected. Models defined by L2 (x) with various choices of μ(η) are investigated in Sec. IV.
The field equation associated with L4 (x) is solved in Sec. V. In Sec. VI, we discuss the
case where the Lagrangian density is given by the linear combination L2+4 (x) of L2 (x) and
L4 (x). The final section is devoted to a summary.

4

 II.

ARATYN-FERREIRA-ZIMERMAN ANSATZ AND HOPF INDEX

To describe the AFZ ansatz, the toroidal coordinates (η, ξ, φ) defined in the previous
section are convenient. The coordinate η ranges from 0 to ∞, while both ξ and φ range
from 0 to 2π. From the relations

III.

MODELS COMPATIBLE WITH THE ARATYN-FERREIRA-ZIMERMAN

ANSATZ

In the previous section, we saw that the AFZ ansatz associated with the boundary condition (2.21) automatically yields configurations n(x) with the Hopf index mn. Of course, the
7

 form of the ansatz for the solution of a field equation strongly depends on the form of the
field equation. In this section, we show that the AFZ ansatz is applicable to some models
other than that of LAFZ (x).

Various ways of choosing μ(η) lead us to some interesting cases. We here describe two of
them.

A.

Case solved by the fifth Painlevé transcendent

In a celebrated paper of 1976, Wu, McCoy, Tracy and Barouch [14] discovered that the
scaling limit of the correlation function of the two-dimensional Ising model is described by
a solution of the (α, β, γ, δ) = (0, 0, 1, −1) case of the third Painlevé equation PIII (α, β, γ, δ)
[12, 13]:

PV (α, β, γ, δ) with δ 6= 0 cannot be reduced to simpler equations and, without loss of generality, δ can be assumed to be − 21 .

It is well known that the solutions of the Painlevé equations have movable poles, that is,
poles whose positions depend on the boundary or initial conditions imposed. If we assume
11

corresponds to a soliton in which the energy distribution is strictly confined within the finite
spatial volume
V = {(η, ξ, φ)| η0 < η < η1 , 0 ≦ ξ, φ ≦ 2π}.

(4.22)

To be more precise, although n(x) in Eq. (4.20) is continuous in the whole R3 , its gradient
∇n(x) is discontinuous on the surfaces η = η0 and η = η1 . Therefore we have to modify
μ(η) in the neighborhood of these surfaces so as to make ∇n(x) continuous. The above
neighborhood can, however, be made as thin as we want. Then a discussion similar to that
around Eq. (2.22) would yield the result QH [n] = −mn. It should be noted that, for
the choice of Eq. (4.8), the large-η behavior of m(t) for general |n/m| =
6 0, ∞ is given by
m(t) ∼ log t and we have Eq. (4.9).

VII.

SUMMARY

We have investigated some classes of nonlinear σ models under the ansatz proposed by
Aratyn, Ferreira, and Zimerman. The models defined by L2 (x), L4 (x), and L2+4 (x) were
shown to be compatible with the ansatz. The L2 (x) model with μ(η) given by Eq. (4.8)

was shown to result in the (α, β, γ, δ) = (0, 0, 0, − 12 ) case of the fifth Poinlevé equation.
The L2 (x) model with μ(η) given by Eq. (4.23) was solved in terms of the Jacobi elliptic

function. The L4 (x) model was solved for general ν(η). The L2+4 (x) model with μ(η) and
ν(η) given by Eq. (6.9) was shown to have an oscillating solution with the period (6.13) and
monotonic solutions determined by Eq. (6.14). We discussed in Secs. IV and VI the choices
of μ(η) and ν(η) that make discussion of the solutions with |m| = |n| simple. It is possible,
however, to make choices of μ(η) and ν(η) so that the discussion of the case |m/n| =
6 1 is
p
simple. For example, if we set μ(η) = {t(η)/[ R(η)sinhη]}m=m0 ,n=n0 with t(η) and R(η)

given by Eqs. (4.2) and (3.8), respectively, the |m/n| = |m0 /n0 | cases of Eq. (4.5) can be
written as Eq. (4.9). Similarly, the |m/n| = |m0 /n0 | case of Eq. (4.5) can be written as Eq.
p
(4.24) if we set μ(η) = {1/[ R(η)sinhη]}m=m0 ,n=n0 .
